hero.headline: Applied AI & Data Systems Builder
hero.subheadline: Governing AI from data foundations to production decisions
hero.narrativeSpine: AI enablement is an operating model problem before it is a technical one.

assertions.explainer: AI introduces variance into systems. Before adding that variance, I exhaust deterministic options—rules, lookups, structured logic. AI solves the residual ambiguity, not the whole problem. This makes systems debuggable and auditable.

Scaling ungoverned AI creates compounding risk. I design validation layers, ownership boundaries, and audit trails before expanding scope. The cost of retrofitting governance is always higher than building it in.

assertions.claim: Design for failure modes, not happy paths
assertions.explainer: Happy paths are easy. I focus on what happens when inputs are malformed, when models hallucinate, when upstream data is late. Systems that handle failure gracefully earn trust; systems that assume success break it.

Automation without oversight becomes a liability. I build systems where humans review before consequential actions, not after failures. 'The AI said so' is never an acceptable answer to a regulator or executive.
Handoffs create gaps where failures hide. I own systems from data ingestion through decision outputs—understanding the full chain means catching problems before they compound downstream.
If a system cannot explain its outputs or prove its inputs were valid, it should not run in production. I treat validation and audit trails as first-class requirements, not afterthoughts.

about.experience: 3+ years building AI-enabled systems for organizations that prioritize reliability over speed
about.focus: Focus areas: data authority, decision support, agent-assisted workflows
